case_name: State of Punjab v. B.P. Maheshwari & Ors.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 439 to 451 of 1961 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revisions Nos. 229 to 241 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEALS Nos. 439 To 451 OF 1961. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revisions Nos. 229 to 241 of 1953.

facts.text: Respondents in the 13 appeals are displaced creditors claiming debts against the State of Punjab under Section 13 of the Displaced Persons (Debts Adjustment) Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in each of these 13 appeals, which have been consolidated for hearing are displaced creditors and the point arising for decision in them is whether they could make a claim under this provision against the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Petition in Civil Appeal 439/1961 was filed by respondent before Subordinate Judge, Amritsar, the Tribunal under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: A petition claiming such relief was filed by the respondent in Civil Appeal 439 of 1961 before the Subordinate Judge, Amritsar who was the Tribunal created under the Act for the purpose of receiving claims under s. 13

facts.text: Similar claims in appeals 440-451/1961 were made before Subordinate Judge, Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: and, similarly, the contesting respondents in the other 12 appeals 440-451 of 1961 made similar claims before the Subordinate Judge, Hissar.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Amritsar rejected preliminary objection by State on May 7, 1953, holding claims maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately the claims were filed and notices issued to the State of Punjab, a preliminary objection to the maintainability of the applications was raised by the State and the Tribunal at Amritsar passed an order on May 7, 1953 rejecting the preliminary objection

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Hissar overruled preliminary objections on May 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Similar objections were also raised before the Subordinate Judge, Hissar who, by orders passed on May 25, 1953, similarly over-ruled the preliminary objections and held that the claims were maintainable before him.

facts.text: State filed revisions in all 13 cases to Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State thereafter filed revisions in all the 13 cases to the High Court of Punjab.

facts.text: Punjab High Court Full Bench held applications under s.13 maintainable against State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of three Judges accordingly heard arguments upon the point raised and held by a unanimous judgment that the applications were maintainable and in doing so over- ruled two earlier decisions which had taken a contrary view.

facts.text: Chief Justice dismissed revision petitions giving effect to Full Bench views.

anchor.surface_text: The revision petitions were thereafter posted for final hearing before the learned Chief Justice who had originally heard them as a Single Judge and who, giving effect to the views expressed by the Full Bench, dismissed them.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to State of Punjab, appeals now before it.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Punjab thereafter applied to this Court for special leave and this being granted, the appeals are now before us.

facts.text: Each contesting respondent is a displaced person; State is not a displaced person.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that each one of the contesting respondents is a displaced person nor is it the contention that the State is a displaced person.

facts.text: In C.A. 439/1961, respondents M/s Okara Grain Buyers Syndicate Ltd. carried on business in Okara, District Montgomery, undivided Punjab (now Pakistan).

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal 439 of 1961 the facts as stated in the application were briefly as follows The respondents are M, s. Okara Grain Buyers Syndicate Ltd. They were originally carrying on business in Okara in District Montgomery of the undivided Punjab now in Pakistan.

facts.text: Government of undivided Punjab instructed respondents to supply 210 bags of imported maize to M/s Anil Starch Products Ltd., Ahmedabad in August 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of the then undivided Punjab instructed the respondents to supply 210 bags of imported maize to M s Anil Starch Products Ltd., Ahmedabad in August 1947.

facts.text: Respondents dispatched goods by train; delivery taken by M/s Anil Starch Products.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents accordingly carried out these instructions and dispatched the goods by train. Delivery of the same was taken by M s Anil Starch Products.

facts.text: After partition, respondents transferred business to Amritsar and registered with Registrar of Companies, Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the partition of India the respondents transferred their place of business from Okara to Amritsar and the Company was duly registered with the Registrar of Companies in the State of Punjab.

facts.text: In July 1948, respondents submitted bill for Rs. 3059/9/- to State Government for maize supplied.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1948 after the respondents moved over to Amritsar, they submitted to the State Government their bill for the value of the maize supplied, being a sum of Rs. 3059/9/- .

facts.text: Anil Starch Products paid Rs. 3059/9/- to Director-General of Food Supplies, East Punjab in Oct-Nov 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were then informed that the Anil Starch Products had made payment of the said sum of Rs. 3059/9/- to the Director-General of Food Supplies. East Punjab in or about October-November, 1948.

facts.text: No payment made by State of Punjab to respondents despite notice.

anchor.surface_text: This was brought to the notice of the Government of the State of Punjab which was required to make the payment to the respondents but as no payment was made,

facts.text: Facts of most applications disputed regarding genuineness and quantum; only preliminary objection decided.

anchor.surface_text: We should, however, hasten to add that in regard to most of these applications made by the respondents to the Tribunal there is a dispute about the facts themselves and about the genuineness and the quantum of the claim which have not yet been investigated,

facts.text: Displaced Persons (Debts Adjustment) Act, 1951 (Central Act LXX of 1951) came into force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 of the Displaced Persons  Debts Adjustment  Act, 1951  Central Act LXX of 1951  which will be referred to hereafter as the Act, enacts Claims by displaced creditors against persons who are not displaced debtors.

facts.text: Partition of India occurred on August 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: When the partition of India was effected and the State of the Punjab was divided between Pakistan and the rest of India,

facts.text: Indian Independence (Rights, Property, Liabilities) Order, 1947 dealt with contracts of undivided Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: This was effected by the Indian Independence  Rights, Property Liabilities  Order, 1947 which in its 8th paragraph dealt with contracts entered into by the Governor-General before the 15th August, 1947  the appointed day  as well as by the undivided province of the Punjab.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 15, 1963 by Ayyangar J.

anchor.surface_text: Union of India . November 15, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.--
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1958, of the Punjab High Court

holdings.text: An application under s.13 of the Displaced Persons (Debts Adjustment) Act, 1951 is maintainable against the State of Punjab as the debt due by the Government or by the State is within the Act by necessary implication.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary implication from integrated scheme of Act, particularly s.32 requiring debts from State as attachable assets for paying capacity; purpose frustrated otherwise; language not intractable.

holdings.text: Under s.13 of the Act a displaced creditor could make a claim against the Government either of the State or of the Union.

anchor.surface_text: As would be seen from the foregoing, the only question that arises for consideration is whether under s. 13 of the Act a displaced creditor could make a claim against the Government either of the State or of the Union, subject

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same scheme and implication applies to both State and Union Governments.
